description:
Leptospira bandrabouensis is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Leptospira, which is known to be the causative agent of the disease leptospirosis. This species was first isolated from environmental samples collected in Bandrabou, a region in Madagascar.

Leptospira bandrabouensis is a spirochete, a type of spiral-shaped bacteria that is motile and can move through liquid environments. It is classified as a pathogenic Leptospira species, meaning it is capable of causing disease in humans and animals.

The genome of Leptospira bandrabouensis has been sequenced, providing insights into its genetic composition and potential virulence factors. Further research is needed to fully understand the epidemiology, clinical manifestations, and ecological role of this newly discovered Leptospira species.
